user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TimerGetIdByName:
```c
int32 OS_TimerGetIdByName(osal_id_t *timer_id, const char *timer_name)
{
    int32          return_code;
    osal_objtype_t objtype;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(timer_id);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(timer_name);

    /*
     * Check our context.  Not allowed to use the timer API from a timer callback.
     * Just interested in the object type returned.
     */
    objtype = OS_ObjectIdToType_Impl(OS_TaskGetId_Impl());
    if (objtype == OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMEBASE)
    {
        return OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdFindByName(OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_TIMECB, timer_name, timer_id);

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_TimerGetIdByName:
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdFindByName(osal_objtype_t idtype, const char *name, osal_id_t *object_id)
{
    int32             return_code;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    /*
     * As this is an internal-only function, calling it with NULL is allowed.
     * This is required by the file/dir/socket API since these DO allow multiple
     * instances of the same name.
     */
    ARGCHECK(name, OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND);
    LENGTHCHECK(name, OS_MAX_API_NAME, OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetByName(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, idtype, name, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        *object_id = token.obj_id;

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the macro OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) is type‑agnostic and only evaluates (ptr) != NULL, it does not declare or convert pointer types nor remove const qualification. In the shown usage (timer_name is const char *), the pointer is already const-qualified, so Rule 8.13 is not violated. (A genuine Rule 8.13 violation would be a function or macro declaring or accepting a non‑const pointer where a const‑qualified pointer could have been used.)
